contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is asked to cause the people of Israel to realize they have disobeyed Yahweh and will suffer because of it. Alternate translation: "You have done a terrible thing." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What is this that you have done?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Deborah asks this question to remind Barak that they fight on the side of Yahweh. Alternate translation: "Remember, Yahweh is leading you." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is not Yahweh leading you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is asked to criticize the people of Reuben because they did not decide to come fight in the battle. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "You should have helped us fight, instead of staying at home and listening to the shepherds playing their pipes for their flocks" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: Why did you sit between the fireplaces, listening to the shepherds playing their pipes for their flocks?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is asked to express anger because the people of the tribe of Dan would not fight for Israel. Alternate translation: "the men of Dan should not have remained on their ships!" or "the people of the tribe of Dan did not help us in the battle. Instead they were wandering around on the sea in ships!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: Dan, why did he wander about on ships?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The women use a question to emphasize that they believe this is what certainly happened. Alternate translation: "They must have so much plunder that it is taking a long time to divide it. They have ... plunder." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Have they not found and divided up the plunderâ€”a womb ... plunder?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The women use a question to emphasize that they believe this is what certainly happened. Alternate translation: "There must be a womb, two wombs for every man ... of those who plunder." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: a womb, two wombs for every man ... of those who plunder?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon uses a question to challenge the stranger's statement that Yahweh was with him. Also, the direct quotation can be stated as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: "We have not seen any wonderful deeds like the ones our fathers told us about when Yahweh brought them up from Egypt." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.glQuote: Where are all his wonderful deeds that our fathers told us about, when they said, 'Did not Yahweh bring us up from Egypt?'

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to ensure Gideon that he is sending him. Here "sent" means Yahweh has appointed Gideon with a specific task. Alternate translation: "I, Yahweh, am sending you!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Have I not sent you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon uses a question to emphasize that he does not think he can rescue the Israelites. Alternate translation: "I cannot possibly rescue the Israelites!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: how can I deliver Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joash uses a question to emphasize that a human should not have to defend a god. Alternate translation: "You should not have to defend Baal." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will you plead the case for Baal?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joash uses a question to emphasize that a human should not have to rescue a god. Alternate translation: "You should not have to save Baal." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will you save him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of the tribe of Ephraim were rebuking Gideon with this rhetorical question for not including them in his army. This can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: "You have not treated us fairly." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What is this you have done to us?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon uses this question to honor the people of Ephraim. Alternate translation: "I have done very little compared with what you have done!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What have I done now compared to you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon was calming the people of Ephraim with this rhetorical question. Alternate translation: "Certainly the grapes you people of Ephraim gleaned are better than what we the descendants of Abiezer gathered from the whole harvest!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Are not the gleanings of Ephraim's grapes better than the full grape harvest of Abiezer?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon and his army defeating the Medianites is spoken of as if it were a grape harvest. The people of Ephraim killing Oreb and Zeeb at the end of the battle is spoken of as if they were gleaning grapes at the end of the harvest. Alternate translation: "What you people of Ephraim did at the end of the battle is more important than what we descendants of Abiezer did at the beginning." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Are not the gleanings of Ephraim's grapes better than the full grape harvest of Abiezer?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon uses this question to honor the people of Ephraim. This can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: "What you have done is more important than what I have done." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What have I accomplished compared to you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders use a question to emphasize that the Israelites have not yet captured Zebah and Zalumnna. Alternate translation: "You have not captured Zebah and Zalmunna yet." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna now in your hand?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders use a question to emphasize that they have no reason to give bread to the Israelites. Alternate translation: "We see no reason to give bread to your army." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: Why should we give bread to your army?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon quotes the people of Succoth as using a question to mock him. Alternate translation: "You have not yet conquered Zebah and Zalmunna." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Have you already conquered Zebah and Zalmunna?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The olive tree is asking this question to refuse to be king. This question can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: "I will not give up my abundance ... over the other trees." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Should I give up my abundance ... over the other trees?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The fig tree is asking this question to refuse to be king. This question can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: "I will not give up my sweetness ... over the other trees." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Should I give up my sweetness ... over the other trees?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The vine is asking this question to refuse to be king. This question can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: "I will not give up my new wine ... over the other trees." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Should I give up my new wine ... over the other trees?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gaal uses a question to emphasize that the people of Shechem should not serve Abimelech. Alternate translation: "We should not serve Abimelech!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Who is Abimelech, and who is Shechem, that we should serve him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gaal uses a question to emphasize that the people of Shechem should not serve Abimelech. Alternate translation: "He is just the son of Jerub Baal, and Zebul is just his officer." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is he not the son of Jerub Baal? Is Zebul not his officer?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gaal uses a question to emphasize that the people of Shechem should not serve Abimelech. Alternate translation: "We should not serve Abimelech!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why should we serve Abimelech?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zebul is scolding Gaal with this rhetorical question. Alternate translation: "You are not speaking proudly now, you" or "You are not proud now, you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Where are your proud words now, you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zebul is quoting Gaal's boast back to Gaal. This can be translated as a statement and as an indirect quote. Alternate translation: "you who said that we should not serve Abimelech." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.glQuote: you who said, 'Who is Abimelech that we should serve him?'

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zebul is challenging Gaal with this rhetorical question. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "Here are the men that you despised." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Are these not the men you despised?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is rebuking the people of Israel for their worship of other gods. The rhetorical question that begins with the words "Did I not deliver you" in verse 11 ends here. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "I am the one who delivered you ... and also from the Sidonians." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: and also from the Sidonians?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with this rhetorical question. The word "their" refers to the Israel. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "therefore, you should not take possession of their land." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: should you now take possession of their land?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "You should only take over the land that Chemosh, your god, gives you." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will you not take over the land that Chemosh, your god, gives you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "You are not better than Balak son of Zippor, who was king of Moab." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Now are you really better than Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. This question can be translated with a statement. Alternate translation: "Yet he did not dare to have an argument with Israel." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Did he dare to have an argument with Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. This question can be translated with a statement. Alternate translation: "Nor did he ever wage war against them." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Did he ever wage war against them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "you should have taken them back during that time." or "now it is too late; you should have taken them back long ago." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: why then did you not take them back during that time?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The angel asks this question as a rebuke. This question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "You should not ask me what my name is." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why do you ask my name?

contextId.occurrenceNote: They ask this question to suggest that they could find Samson a wife among their own people. This question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "Surely there are women among your people whom you could marry." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is there not a woman among the daughters of your relatives, or among all our people?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is asked to rebuke Samson. This question can be written as a statement. You can make explicit the reason his parents do not want him to marry a Philistine. Alternate translation: "You really should not marry a Philistine woman because the Philistine people do not worship Yahweh." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: Are you going to take a wife from the uncircumcised Philistines?

contextId.occurrenceNote: They ask her this question to accuse her of doing evil. This question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "You have brought us here to make us poor!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Did you invite us here in order to make us poor?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Samson was rebuking her for demanding that he tell her the answer. This question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "I have not even told my father or mother. I will not tell you." or "you should not demand that I tell you, since I have not even told my parents, and they are closer to me than you are." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: if I have not told my father or my mother, should I tell you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the answer to the riddle. It may be written as a statement instead of as questions. If necessary it could be made clear how this relates to the riddle by adding more information. Alternate translation: "Honey is sweet and a lion is strong." or "Honey is sweet and it came out of a lion." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: What is sweeter than honey? What is stronger than a lion?

contextId.occurrenceNote: He asks this question to imply that Samson should agree with him. This question may be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "I hope you agree." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: is she not?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The men of Judah ask Samson these questions to rebuke him. This questions may be written as a statements. Alternate translation: "You know that the Philistines are rulers over us but you act like they are not. What you have done has caused us great harm." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do you not know that the Philistines are rulers over us? What is this you have done to us?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Delilah asks this question to say that if Samson really loved her he would tell her his secrets. This question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "When you say 'I love you,' you are lying because you do not share your secrets with me." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How can you say, 'I love you,' when you do not share your secrets with me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is asked sarcastically and means that they should be doing the opposite. This question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "You should be acting now!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.glQuote: Are you doing nothing?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The five men asked this question to suggest and encourage the men that they should steal the idols. This can be written as a statement, and the implied information may be given in a parenthetical phrase. Alternate translation: "these houses contain an ephod, ... metal figure. (They were suggesting that the men steal these things.) Decide ... will do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: in these houses there are an ephod, ... metal figure? Decide ... will do

contextId.occurrenceNote: They ask this as a rhetorical question to imply that it is true. This question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "It is better for you to be priest for a tribe and a clan in Israel than for just the house of one man." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is it better for you to be priest for the house of one man ... a clan in Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is a rebuke. It can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "You should not have called your men together to chase us." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why have you been called together?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah asks this question to emphasize that he no longer has the things that are important to him. Alternate translation: "I have nothing left." or "You have taken everything that is important to me." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What else do I have left?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah asks this question to emphasize that the Danites definitely know what is bothering him. Alternate translation: "You know that I am greatly distressed!'" or "You know how much I am bothered by what you have done to me!'" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How can you ask me, 'What is bothering you?'

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel used this rhetorical question to express their deep sadness. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "Oh Yahweh, we are so sad that one of the tribes of Israel has been completely destroyed." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why, Yahweh, God of Israel, has this happened to Israel, that one of our tribes should be missing today?
